title: Lions QB Matthew Stafford has no interest in spoof video that depicts him as Joker
text:
Matthew Stafford doesn’t need any extra motivation for Monday night’s game against the Green Bay Packers, and certainly not from Bleacher Report.

Stafford insisted Wednesday that he had not seen the sports and culture website’s animated “Gridiron Heights” video that depicted him as the Joker and took a comedic look at his place among NFL quarterbacks.

Among other things, the minute-long video depicted the Detroit Lions quarterback giving Calvin Johnson a bath while saying, “Megatron always tells me to be like the Lions greats and retire early,” and a Kirk Cousins caricature introducing him as “Pad Statford.”

“I didn’t see it,” Stafford said. “Somebody disrespecting us?”

Asked if he wanted to watch the video in the locker room, Stafford said: “That’s all (right). I’ll not look at it some other time.”

Bleacher Report declined to make the animator of the weekly series available for an interview, but several Lions players shared their dislike for the piece on social media.

“Wtf is this”? running back Kerryon Johnson tweeted.

“Just some lowlife who has nothing better to do,” responded safety Tracy Walker.

Stafford is off to a nice start this season after a disappointing 2018.

He has a career-high 102.6 passer rating and nine touchdowns against two interceptions, and the Lions are 2-1-1 and in second place in the NFC North.

Stafford said the hip injury he played through in a Week 4 loss to the Kansas City Chiefs “feels good” and “feels better” after last week’s bye, and he said “hope not” when asked if he expects it to be an issue going forward.

“Tough to say (how much it affected me against the Chiefs),” he said. “I just, I was out there, I’m going to be out there as much as I possibly can, you guys know that, so I was just out there playing. Felt good enough to go out and play and execute at a decent level.”

For the Lions to beat the Packers for the third straight time at Lambeau Field, something that hasn’t happened since 1986-88, they’ll need Stafford to play at an even higher level than he has through the season’s first four weeks.

The Packers rank among the NFL leaders in scoring defense and are tied for the NFL lead in turnover margin. They have seven interceptions and four fumble recoveries this season, and have done a good job forcing quarterback fumbles with their pass rush.

“I think their front four or front five, however many guys they want to rush, do a great job of affecting the quarterback’s pocket,” Stafford said. “They’ve been stripping the ball from the quarterback, they’ve also been getting interceptions in the back end. That’s both scheme and players.”

Lions offensive coordinator Darrell Bevell called the Packers' defense one “that really thrives” on creating turnovers, and said limiting turnovers has been an emphasis for his offense this week.

Stafford, who has lost two fumbles and has thrown two interceptions this season, said that is a personal focus for the next 12 weeks.

“It’s hugely important,” he said. “Every single game you go play in, turnovers are the No. 1 leading stat in determining the outcome of the game. The more that we can retain the ball and then get it back from their offense, the better we’re going to be.”

Follow Dave Birkett on Twitter @davebirkett
description: Detroit Lions quarterback Matthew Stafford ignored video spoofing him as Joker, and says his hip injury feels better after a week of rest.
